metadata.name: CLDCSMC #143
metadata.description:
This token was created for THE PASSAGE: Pitch Drop experience, an interactive minting experience where your choices determine the design of your token.

To take part, please purchase an Edition 5 Coin on fx(hash) by HERE & NOW. The artwork and experience draw inspiration from the 'The Pitch Drop Experiment': the world's longest-running laboratory experiment. Since 1927, only nine drops of pitch have fallen, and it has never been witnessed live.

ùêÇùêãùêÉùêÇùêíùêåùêÇ is a story about post-civilization and post-nature.
Inspired by the explorations of alternate life forms.

GAN model training data credits: Janie Fitzgerald.

https://ivonatau.com/flora-solaris

2023

metadata.name: WootScoot Daily Mint-Pass #10
metadata.description:
A Mint-Pass for the WootScoot Daily account.

Gives you access to:
- 24h reserves on all the upcoming dailies
- cheaper prices on all the upcoming dailies
- reserves on WootScoot longform pieces

---

Press space to save the current frame.
Click/Tap the screen to pause/play the animation.
Press -M to toggle mouse follow mode.
Press -T to show/hide the text on the pass

---

Wouter Missler, 2022.

metadata.name: The Woodcarver's apprentice #156
metadata.description:
A mix of aesthetics from the Ukiyo-e and Shin-hanga woodblock movements, with modern elements.  

ukiyo-e (ÊµÆ‰∏ñÁµµ) = "pictures of the floating world", which peaked in the late 19th century. 
shin-hanga (Êñ∞ÁâàÁîª) = "new prints", from roughly the 1920-1950s. 

Some comparisons between the prints of the Japanese masters and gen-art: 

* The number of prints. Based on how well a piece was received, the publisher could decide to produce more copies, usually in batches of 200. Compare this to limiting the edition size on fx(hash). The initial prints would have sharp lines and accurately coloured areas. Very popular prints with thousands of impressions would slowly degrade the blocks, leaving final prints with worn-out linework and colours that weren't true to originals.  

* Woodblock prints were actually a collab between the artist, the wood carver, and the printer. In many cases only the artist and publisher were recognized on the final prints. It was usually the publisher who owned the woodblock, not the artist. Often the artist was considered a worker, contracted at the request of the publisher or patrons funding the project. Compare this to the NFT space, where ownership is carved onto the blockchain, and artists have freedom to create whatever they wish. 

* Copyminters.... Similar to the NFT world, fake publishers sprang up from time to time, who would reproduce famous prints. Enji Takamizawa was one such counterfeiter, who was able to skilfully produce woodblocks replicating originals down to the wood grain! 

* While fine-quality woodblock prints from the Edo era command huge auction prices today, they were in reality affordable art for the regular people of their time. NFTs are similar in this light, where we can enjoy pieces at home rather than say, visiting galleries or museums of unattainable art. 



Additional querystring params (use when viewing in a separate window) 

* fullsize=true (33 megapixel output) 
* colourcorrect=false 
* grain=false 
* border=false 



Licenses included in source. Relying on: 

* PIXIJS for drawing 
* JSTS for geometry functions 
* chromajs for colour functions 
* noise and gaussian helpers from p5js

metadata.name: Rebug #177
metadata.description:
A debug view of the underlying particulate algorithm of Atoms' Gaze and Quantum Folly. Refined as a gift for collectors.

Enjoy watching the structures form. Once it's fully rendered you can download a full resolution image of 3508 x 4961 px by ***double clicking/tapping***. At this size the piece is printable at A3 size at 300 dpi. If you're interested in acquiring a signed print please contact @KRANKARTA.

Created on Chrome desktop 103.0 on 2022-08-06 in javascript and GLSL. Results on other browsers/devices may vary.

metadata.name: barcodes #16
metadata.description:
The title of my collection is ‚Äúbarcodes‚Äù, as unique visual identifiers for their respective generative token. 

Barcodes initially displayed data by varying width, spacing, and size of the lines. Today, we can additionally separate barcodes by color and hidden layers.

In our realm of little dots and noise, we can distinguish data (token holder, contract address, purchase history) using these features, but we can add one more:

The time it takes for the ‚Äúpitch to drop‚Äù. The pace of the barcode‚Äôs formation.

metadata.name: Marble, Opulence #72
metadata.description: Opulent Marble... made with pure p5js code and a WebGL shader.

metadata.name: ASSEMBLING MACHINE #131
metadata.description:
The machine never sleeps.
Build. Construct. Develop. Create. Form. Produce. Generate. Repeat.
---------------
Collectors at the highest tier (125 tez) may claim a signed 8‚Äùx10‚Äù print of their mint. Please look for details about prints on Twitter (@teaboswell), or contact me directly
---------------
CONTROLS:
A - Toggle loading animation (off by default to improve performance)
S - Download image
Double tap (mobile) - Download image
1-6 - Modify scale (1 = default, 2048 x 2730px, 6 = maximum, 12288 x 16380px (very performance intensive, will take a long time to render))
F - Fit to current screen size
G - Toggle grain overlay
L - Toggle background grid lines
B - Cycle border sizes (0 -> 100 -> 200 -> 300px)

You can modify the x and y url parameters to set a custom size. Note that the image will change to fit the new size, but overall drawing style, colors, etc. will remain the same.
(For example, for a 1000x2000 image, add &x=1000&y=2000)
---------------
teaboswell 2022
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information

metadata.name: DEAMBULATOIRE VIII #27
metadata.description:
To view/purchase 3d prints and concrete sculpture of this NFT, visit project page at:
https://davidumemoto.com/deambulatoire-no8

On desktop, open project in live view:
Rotate and zoom with the mouse to explore the model

Click ‚ÄúS‚Äù to download STL 3D file (printable )
Click ‚ÄúG‚Äù to download GLTF 3D file 
Click ‚ÄúP‚Äù to download PNG (3600x3600)
Click ‚ÄúA‚Äù to download Animated GIF (1200x1200)

The physical version is a cast concrete sculpture produced in 3 editions for David Umemoto‚Äôs ‚ÄúPrimitives‚Äù exhibition. It was presented at OSA / J.W. Sterlick Gallery in Ottawa from Oct 6 - Nov 13 2022 and at Art Toronto from Oct 27 ‚Äì 30 2022

The digital generative token expresses various possible stages in the lifetime of what that object could be as a human scale architectural work. Is it being built or is in decay?  It‚Äôs in that brief moment when something is being built or dismantled that you can see and understand its inner structure, that you have the privileged access to the secrets of its conception. It‚Äôs vulnerable and fragile but also light and elegant. The unfinished quality leaves place for imagination to guess where the piece came or is going.

One of the main purpose of this token is the possibility to have it 3D printed. The default STL output size 78x78x78 mm is the minimal recommended size for printing. Large sizes may produce better quality prints and minimize breakage risks.

metadata.name: In Due Time #132
metadata.description:
‚ÄúIn Due Time‚Äù is a collaborative generative collection between artists Melissa Wiederrecht and Amber Vittoria. Inspired by Wiederrecht‚Äôs mastery of line and Vittoria‚Äôs notable palette, this 1/1/250 series captures the present moment. It serves as a reminder that we are more similar than we are different, leveraging homogeneous shapes to create distinctive compositions.

Vittoria‚Äôs poem for the collection:

‚ÄúIn Due Time‚Äù
We will all become
Particles dancing
Across the skyline.

The artwork listed is indeed authentic, created by, and copyright to artists Melissa Wiederrecht and Amber Vittoria; the purchase of this NFT is a purchase of the asset, not of the copyright.

-------------------------------------------

To save a high-resolution image for printing, click ‚Äúopen‚Äù under the image on the page for your token, and then hit:

Digits ‚Äú1‚Äù through ‚Äú9‚Äù to get an image that is 1000 through 9000px tall.  This may take a while, depending on the size and your computer, so please be patient.

metadata.name: ProtoByte: Scyphozoa.01 #198
metadata.description:
Scyphozoa.01 is the alpha release built with my new ProtoByte.ts library.

ProtoByte is a Verlet Integration-based creative coding framework designed to simulate and render organic, aesthetic structures and behaviors. It combines physics simulation with artistic visualization, offering versatile tools for creating dynamic, whimsically lifelike forms and interactions in 3D.

ProtoByte.ts
Release notes:

As I begin to release #genart projects like Scyphozoa.01, and soon enough the ProtoByte.ts library itself, I thought it would be useful to share my thoughts and hopes for the project. 

I plan to vary minor and major releases in alignment with library development. This drop reflects a minor (though quite significant personally) internal release. Minor releases will generally have more affordable pricing and larger editions.

Project Goals:
1.  Release a fun, distinct and highly useable library, with advanced behavior for creative coding that supports existing core libs such as @threejs, @p5jsArt, @processingOrg, @babylonjs.

2. Develop and nurture a userbase that both create with and contribute to the overall ProtoByte.ts project.

3. Develop supporting pedagogy to continue my 30 year odyssey in #creativecoding. 

4. Continue to contribute to the mission for increased adoption, growth and value of Web3 as a major creative space/art marketplace.

metadata.name: Take Wing #16
metadata.description:
‚ÄúTake Wing‚Äù is a generative art collection depicting the hope, optimism, and thrilling excitement of a person taking off, gaining traction, and soaring to new heights and off into the great unknown.  

The algorithm behind the piece stems from an attempt to go back to art fundamentals and codify composition rules and painterly techniques into a generative form - taking into account focal points, contrast, eye movement, and color theory while still giving the algorithm freedom to explore random color palettes, random flow field movement, random brush strokes, and many other degrees of freedom.

The collection is made in pure code with p5.js and a few GLSL fragment shaders.

The piece has been created to be exhibited at "In Touch" with VerticalCryptoArt in Berlin in September 2022, curated by Anika Meier.

------------------------------------------------

To get a (somewhat) high-resolution output, open the live view of your token, and then edit the URL adding &h=5400 at the end of it.  5400 is the tallest you can go, but you can also put a smaller number if you desire.  Be aware that this will only work on a machine with a very beefy GPU, and even then may take a bit, so please be patient!

metadata.name: Merkki #34
metadata.description:
Merkki is an exploration of primitive forms, randomness and bold lines.
Drawing inspiration from mid-70s iconic single-color logotypes, this project revolves heavily around constraints and minimalism.

- 5 different shape types
- 3 grid sizes
- Mostly monochrome, with occasional color accents

Press ‚Äús‚Äù to save a 4000x4000px image.

metadata.name: Poems in the Public Domain #189
metadata.description:
POEMS IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN [PITPD] represents a new form of poetic anthology‚Äîone that celebrates the role of the reader in shaping the life of a poem. In this unique art piece, 14 readers take turns discovering 30 classic poems. We invite collectors to explore this compendium, selected to present a diverse, engaging archive that acknowledges the importance of certain seminal works in shaping our collective unconscious. 

Inspired by Roland Barthe's maxim, "those who fail to reread are obliged to read the same story everywhere," each reader is represented by multiple pen colors & new marginalia, suggesting the crucial act of rereading. 

The verses vanish, just like our memory of their exact words might fade, but distilled, standout moments of personal connection remain. In time, even these wane, providing a scarcely perceptible backdrop as the poem is discovered & interpreted anew. 

PITPD explores authorship. When a poem enters the public domain, it no longer belongs to its author but to its readers. In the intimate moments we read a poem, we link it to our private, pulsating worlds & help ensure others will read it, too. If history‚Äôs palms hadn‚Äôt held Sappho‚Äôs words, our fingers wouldn‚Äôt hold them now. 

Readers write poetry‚Äôs survival. 

Each iteration of PITPD traces a narrative that can play for hours without repeating. Some 89% of iterations chronicle the life of a single poem, while 11% include multiple poems, intentionally surveying intertextuality. Taking advantage of the generative medium, embodied readership is represented via dynamic handwriting, dancing markings, algorithmic paper aging, coded stains, & other effects.

Spacebar pauses & resumes the animation. Refreshing the browser window restarts it. For those interested in the underlying code, please open the browser console. This collection‚Äôs ciphers, too, are in the public domain.

Additional information can be found in the companion article on fx(text): fxhash.xyz/article/poems-in-the-public-domain-marginalia-as-living-verse

metadata.name: Sand waves #115
metadata.description: A sea that will never know a storm, let your mind wander through the sand waves rhythm!

metadata.name: ecolog√≠as - B #1184
metadata.description:
ecolog√≠as - B

water is the medium where life first appeared in our planet. Water is also indispensable for the continuation of the life that emerged from - and with - it. The advent of AI species and their introduction into society is a new form of cambrian explosion. What is their medium? What is their water? How scarce and precious will it be for them? AI entities are not foreign to human resource necessities, though. The water that is essential to our human life will also be so for machines, as their energy still depends on our natural resources. Therefore, the ecologies of humans and machines will have, at least, the same elements as the ecologies of humans. AIs may help us reach better balances, only if we employ them to do so and if we teach them to help us.

ecolog√≠as-B is an entity that is part of a broader ecology. Released on occasion of the show "Unbound - Ecology in the Age of Machines" at Unit London. The data generated by this entity is read by a different piece minted on Ethereum, creating a link between Tezos and Ethereum, a metaphor for an ecology of blockchains.

it shares a common element with two other works released on fxhash: ecolog√≠as A and ecolog√≠as C, all of them contributing data to aforementioned pieces.

read more at https://www.iillucid.com/ecologias

15% of primary sales are donated to institutions working towards improving biodiversity and environmental efforts.

Marcelo Soria-Rodr√≠guez, @msoriaro
CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/

Built on p5.js and p5.Framebuffer (massive thanks and respect to the corresponding authors)

append &pd=N (N a number) to the URL in live view to increase/decrease resolution
press s to save current image in current resolution
press z,x,g,b,n followed by +/- to increase/decrease, respectively, brightness, contrast, gamma, blur, noise
press l (as in loop) to pause/resume the piece
